content.description: Climb the arete to face.
content.protection: 11 bolts, two bolt anchor w/ chains
content.location: Lower Pond Area   #79 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: Start on the same first bolt as Easy Pool and proceed to the left and up.  The route goes straight up from there.  Be careful not to scrape yourself as the rock contains edges which can be sharp enough to draw blood.  Nice view from the top, scary getting there.
content.protection: 6 bolts to mussy hooks. Bolts  5 and 6 are quite far apart compared to the other routes on the face.
content.location: Left-most of three sport routes, immediately to the left of the upper pond.

content.description: Just left of the Weak Sister

Start by climbing up and easy ramp to a break.  Clip a bolt and make some pumpy moves to get over the overhanging crux section.  After the bulge the route eases off past another bolt or 2.  Short climb, but a pretty fun sequence through the crux.
content.location: Just to the left of Winds of Change.  About 75 yards up the the hill from the steep overhanging Desert Devil wall.

content.description: Quite thin face climbing past the first bolt to a break and many pockets on a vertical face, then past easier and steeper jug climbing to the anchors.
content.location: up the hill from the Desert Devil area, but before Pocket Party Wall.  There's a pretty obviously layback flake on the route(unknown name) 10' to the left of this one.

content.description: A fun route!  Fairly sustained and well-protected.  Go up the face past a couple bolts, then out right past several more bolts.  Great holds right where you need them.
content.protection: At least 6 bolts to 2 mussy hook anchors
content.location: As you make your way west from the pond, you'll pass  an overhanging formation with several .12+++ routes.   Continue to a chimney.  Weak Sister starts right of the chimney,

content.description:
Relatively new route, barely to the right of "Next To Nothing" and climbing to its anchor. Pretty easy climbing. Let's say 5.6 for now.

 If you have any info about this route, please submit an edit or drop a comment.
content.protection: 4 bolts, and two-bolt anchor with one oval link each. Shares anchor with "Next To Nothing".
content.location: Barely to the right of "Next to Nothing" and climbing to the same anchor.

content.description: I couldn't find info on this, so I am posting the route here in hopes someone can help. Starts with hands high and virtually no feet.  Lots of choss came off as it was climbed and hardware looks new.  First few moves are hard until you gain feet.  Overcome a bulge to access much easier climbing.  Ends at rap rings.  *If you know anything about this route, please chime in or go to the appropriate channels to get the correct info here on it.
content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with rings
content.location: About 20 feet to the right of Pockets are Stronger than Partners. Starts at/above head height.

content.description: Starts out on a nice face. Gets crispy and has an interesting finish. (* FA info: This line on the Bartuni face was originally bolted by Greg Varela and Chad Cooper. I reconfigured it to its current form. FA)
content.location: Just to the right of Mona Lisa. (Time Share is misidentified in the 9-2008 Karabin guide. It should be #31 and Blisters in the Sun should be #32)

content.description: Climbing on broken face.
content.location: Lower Pond Area   #86 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: It's hard to call this one more difficult than the two 10b's framing it, but it is easy to say that this is a fun route. A bit crimpy down low (like the other two routes) and then you just keep flowing up the pockets to the final horizontal break for a brief rest before the slightly overhanging finish. If you keep the momentum going, it will be easy. If you stall, maybe not so much.
content.protection: 8 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with mussy hooks
content.location:
The route between "the pockets". This is the first line of newer looking bolts to the right of those classic Queen Creek ring shuts on Pocket Party (pocket party is nearer the left edge of the arete). Located on the other side from the Pocket Puzzle face that is located on the same monolith. 

  #31 in the 2006 version of Marty Karabin's Road Area foldout

content.description: A fun route with a couple of cruxy parts.  Follow 10 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor
content.location: On the right side of the big face, just left of Pocket Puzzle.

content.description: Pocketed face.
content.location: Near left end of main wall at Upper Pond West.

climbs.name: Rocky Horror Picture Show
climbs.fa: Marty Karabin, William Haeberle, Bill Paul - May '07

content.description: Start up an overhung series of moves to gsin B1 and pull over the bulge to B2.  Continue up a sloped face trending left with the bolt line.  Pull another overhang and continue up the headwall to the chain anchors.
content.location: Located on the right edge of the overhang.  Right of 'Just Can't Get Any', 5.12b.

content.description: Climb open book to face. Crux is before 2nd bolt and before 8th bolt. Before clipping the 8th bolt there is ledge fall potential, heads up!
content.location: Lower Pond Area   #81 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

climbs.name: Return From the Great Mormon Experience

content.description:
One of the better routes at the Pond! 

  Start by stemming over to the first bolt, then proceed up through a few increasingly difficult sections to the technical crux deadpoint.  Get a good shake and blast up the route's second half, which is comprised of fun jugs on solid red rock. 

  There is still a bit of loose rock on the arete at the bottom near the 3rd and 4th bolts that should probably be cleaned off, since it is right above the belayer. 

  It is possible to set up a TR on this climb-- there's a bolt a few feet above the anchors to which one can clip a long runner so that you can safely climb down to the anchor hooks.
content.location: The prominent slightly overhanging long face at the lower pond, just to the left of a gully.  #80 in the Karabin guide.

climbs.name: Princess Jordini and Her Magic Flute

content.description: far west end of the pond area

climbs.name: Pony Express
climbs.fa: Robert Olson, Marty Karabin, Bill Paul

content.description: Short route, but fun.  Low angle pocketed face to ledge top out.
content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor over ledge
content.location: From the pond, go left to the first trail to the top.  This is on the trail, last route on the left.

content.description:
The route is pretty fun and a bit overhung but not to bad. 

  Crux: Theres a V3 as soon as you head right on the route and break away from OUT ON PAROLE. Small crimps but if you get your feet set you're money. After that its just pumpy and sharp with good holds to the finish.
content.location: The route starts on OUT ON PAROLE (5.10C) and then olits right for 2 bolts and then ends at the same anchors as OUT ON PAROLE. This is to the left of the project next to The Emerald.

content.description: This route starts at Pocket Warmer, but instead of moving up, step right onto the obvious jug foothold and head right to your first bolt. Once you are even with the first bolt head up on good holds to 2 chain anchors with carabiners (Don't take the carabiners, I cut the chain length to run with the biners).  This route was bolted with the 1st time leader in mind, aka - big holds, close bolts, and short.   As with any new route some holds might still be a bit crispy, but it felt solid on my last cleaning.
content.location: Starts at Pocket Warmer

content.description: Excellent climb up steep pocketed face.  Great holds, fun moves, sustained with one good rest.
content.protection: Bolts & two bolt anchor with mussy hooks.
content.location: West-facing wall at right end of Upper Pond West.  Just around corner from monster overhang.

content.description: Nice little pocketed climb with plenty of big holes to hang from.
content.protection: Bolts & Mussy Hooks at the anchor
content.location: This is located on a little west-facing buttress about fifteen feet right of the start to Pocket Pow-Wow.

climbs.name: Pocket Pulling Pansies
climbs.fa: Eric Agaciewski, Chris Bastek, Steve Dison(Fall 2008)

content.description: More pocket pulling fun.
content.location: Route left of Pocket Party

content.description: Steep crimping to pockets, moving slightly left, then a short traverse right and up vertical wall to chains.
content.location: Right hand side of south-facing wall with Pocket Party on it (two to the right of that route).

content.description: Fun and pumpy!
content.location: 2 routes left of Pocket Pow-wow

content.description: Climb the slab to a bulge. Break right if you are going for the .12
content.location: Just left of the main overhang at the Pond area.

content.description: Getting of the ground is much harder than the rest of the climb.  Long climb with huge hands and feet the whole way.
content.protection: 5 bolts & Mussy Hooks at the anchors
content.location: Holey Void area past fat boy and a little above

content.description: Between Nothing Shocking (arête) on the left and Nothings Right. Start by pulling up over a small roof.
content.protection: Bolts & Mussy Hooks at the Anchors

content.description: Head up and right along a seam using a pod-like feature here and there. Cross back over left and up to finish along and about the bolt line.
content.location: Hike up and around the Upper Pond Area to what is commonly known as The Holey Void Area. Find Nothing's Left and Nothing's Right and head across the drainage/stream/waterfall area to find an east facing wall. This route is the right-most route on the wall. CAUTION: An active bee hive has been at the bottom of this and Is Nothing Sacred for a few years. Proceed with extreme caution.

climbs.name: Nothing To It
climbs.fa: Scott Aldinger, Fred AmRhein & Lisa Schmitz, Dec 1996

content.description: A short and pumpy route.  Climb the overhanging pocketed face to the top.
content.protection: 5 bolts with two anchor bolts on top.  This climb is well protected and the bolts are closely spaced.
content.location: Located in the Holey Void area of the Upper Pond West, this climb is on a face left (west) around the corner from Nothing's Left/Nothing's Right.  Start on a small ledge in front of a large boulder. There is a large, left-leaning crack at the start of the climb.

content.description: Fun climb with bomber holds.  As with the other climbs nearby the crux is the start (first 2 bolts).  Stepping to the left significantly eases the sequence but may not be in the spirit of the climb.  While nothing broke off for me, some of the rock was loose.
content.location: Holey Void region.  Climbs the arete between "Nothing Becomes Her" and "Nothing's Left".  #12 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide.

content.description: The crux?  IMHO I thought that there were three of them; one minor one at the second bolt and two leaving the horizontals.  Fun route, but harder than a 10c (I think). This is a fun route, but a bit crimpy and a bit of a head trip near the top.
content.location: This route starts on an overhanging bulge that leads to a ledge, just right of "In Seam" (look for an obvious vertical shallow crack) on the face just left of the main (tallest) wall.

content.description: Bouldery start to seams/face.
content.location: Hike up and around to the west past the Upper Pond Routes. FInd an east facing wall to the west of Nothing Left and Nothing Right in what is commonly known as the Holey Void Area. Cross a small drainage/stream/waterfall area (wet and flowing in the winter/spring) and up to the bottom of the wall. Nothing But Air is the route on the left end of the wall. CAUTION: An active bee hive has been at the bottom center of this wall for the past few years and could be a problem. Proceed with extreme caution accordingly.

content.description: Bolted climb facing west, around the corner from Nothing's Shocking.
content.location: It's on the rock face immediately to the right of the small waterfall. Between Nothing To It and Nothing Shocking.

content.description: Right facing dihedral to arete and face.
content.protection: 7 bolts, two bolt anchor w/ rings.
content.location: Lower Pond Area   #85 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: Lower Pond area. 9 bolt sport
content.location: Lower Pond / #83 on fold-out map

content.description: A short climb that can be a bit thought-provoking for the beginner leader up to the 2nd bolt.  The 2nd bolt is a bit high and the climb can be scary for a beginning leader between the 1st and 2nd bolts. Above the 2nd bolt, the climbing eases to slab past 2 more bolts.
content.location: Located in the far west corner of the Upper Pond West.  Start the face climb on a small ledge just to the right of a big corner.

content.description: Obvious large curving crack that widens to OW toward the top of a prominent buttress in the Upper Pond.
content.location: On prominent white buttress in the west end of the Upper Pond area. On the approach to the Upper Pond the start of the route is on the right.

content.description: Stemming a dihedral eventually leads you up to the overhanging crack that constitutes the crux section on this work of art [okay, a little hyperbolic]. From here, you will utilize lie backs, finger locks, and even a hand jam to surmount the bulge. This is an engaging route with a great overhanging finish and is at least as fun as the over hyped edging of The Soft Parade.
content.location: Route #21 in the 2006 edition of Marty Karabin's Road Area guide. Go far left on the tall wall that is just left of Pocket Puzzle to find the bolted chute that is the start of Mona Lisa.

content.description: Yet another crimpy, slightly overhanging face climb.
content.location: Just left of the easier climbs

content.description: Climb pocketed face. Pumpy!
content.location: Upper Pond Area   #44 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: Technical burliness awaits you from the start of Loc-Tite with small footholds, monos, and general pocketed goodness. Above the initial crux section, there is still a somewhat heady slab/bulge move that needs to be surmounted before claiming this quality route. Marty (the FAist) once told me the kids team at PRG were calling it a 5.10. Damn kids and their tiny fingers.
content.location: Several walls to the left of Pocket Puzzle, you will scramble around and up to a recessed alcove with an obvious, almost blank face that has Loc-Tite and the neighboring Endomorph Man (12b).

content.description: Bolt to ledge. 5 bolt face to top. Route #84 in MK pocket guide.
content.location: Lower Pond Wall:   Bolted line to the right of Ninja School, but it begins near the base of Noah's Ark.

climbs.name: Leave Your Money On the Dresser
climbs.fa: Bill Paul, Marty Karabin, Robert Olson

content.description: Slightly overhanging, short climb that's worth the time.  A bit tricky to get right, but plenty of different options.  Crux is between 2nd and 3rd bolt.
content.location: Located 10 meters to the right of Cowgirl(5.9) on the overhanging face with the broken corner at the top. #48 (5.10b) on Marty Karabin's Road Area Guide.  Walk off is possible, but rap off is easier.

content.description: Similar to the Warden at the top, but with a much easier start. Both routes get early afternoon shade.
content.location: Left of the Warden. Starts on the flake.

content.description: 3 Bolts to Rings at the top. The line starts on a pinch and moves into a small lip and then you pull on crimps to a jug while fighting the slight overhang and finish.
content.protection: 3 draws and a top to rings.
content.location: Next to Arete Horizon starting under the lip/roof.

content.description: Thin pocket moves to slightly overhanging face and more pockets.
content.location: Same as Nothing But Air, Hike up and around past the Upper Pond Area to what is commonly known as The Holey Void Area to an east facing wall west of Nothing's Left and Nothing's Right. Cross a small drainage/stream/waterfall area and up to the wall. CAUTION: An active bee hive has been at the bottom of this route for a few years. Proceed with extreme caution accordingly. Is Nothing Sacred is the center route on the wall.

content.description: Awkward belay stance. Traverse left about 3 bolts before heading up and right. Bolt hangers are old leper style. There is only 1 anchor...an old hanger with 2 rusted chain links. In Marty's guide it says this was done in 1995... probably hasn't had anyone on it since then, ha.
content.location: This is the rightmost route on the wall to the right of the pond.

content.description: Nice route.  The crux is just above the first horizontal.  I liked the variation in the moves on this climb.
content.protection: Eight bolts & 2 bolt anchor w/ Mussy Hooks
content.location: Located just right of Casting Shadows, the route follows the obvious vertical seam in the face (hangers are located climbers left of the seam).  The wall is just after the main (tallest)wall with the classic climb "The soft Parade".

content.description: Another overhanging crimpy/pocketed line. This one is a little shorter.
content.location: To the right of the main overhang.

content.description: Another crimpy overhanging line, to the right of Hot Line on the main overhang.
content.location: Just right of the break after the main wall

content.description: Just East of Nothings Right
Bouldery start following bolts to Chains.
content.location:
To the right of Christmas Chocolate about 6'. 

  Note: This route is not in the Marty's map for the area. It is right of #23 Christmas Chocolate and left of #24 Casting Shadows. 

  Update: Now one route left of Casting Couch (5.9), which is a new route left of Casting Shadows.

climbs.name: Gatekeeper
climbs.fa: FA: Craig Keaty, SA: Craig Streit (November 2018)

content.description: This route was intended as an alternative access to the three 5.12 routes above, but it can be climbed by itself as well.  Stay to the right on the face if you want more of a challenge.
content.location: This route is below "Hot Line", "Hot House" and "Mistaken Identity" and gives another option for access to these routes.  It's west of the pond.

content.description: Well-pocketed route. A bit tricky up near the finish, going over a bulge that might get your attention (@ fourth bolt)
content.location: Located just to the right of Sappy Love Song (between that and Christmas Chocolate)

climbs.name: Fat Boy Goes to the Pond

content.description: Very short pocketed 3-bolt face
content.location: On formation left of Sappy Love Song.

content.description: Crux it out on some THIN holds!
content.protection: 5 bolts to shared anchor with Loc-Tite.
content.location: Right of Loc Tite

content.description: The harder line to the left of Desert Devil. Apparently holds have broken...
content.location: Left of DD

content.description: Fun route, thin at the start getting easier towards the top.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2 bolt anchor w/ mussy hooks
content.location: First face left of the upper pond.  Three routes on the face, this route starts on the ledge and goes right up the middle.

climbs.name: Dreaming of Chocolate Bunnies
climbs.fa: Christopher Bastek, Michael Farrar, Stuart Speckner April 4 2020

content.description: Left of Sappy Love Song. Climb face to arete past 6 bolts to Fixe ring anchors. Be careful of rock at base that is being held in by some roots.
content.location: Left of Sappy Love Song

content.description: one long V4
content.location: up the middle of steepest wall at the pond

content.description: 3 bolts to anchor. Easy hands harder feet.
content.protection: 3 Bolts and an Anchor at the top.
content.location: Almost as far left as you can go at the pond. Number 3 on the Marty Map.

content.description:
Fun moves to good pockets and a bunch of small crimps. The route is overhung and gets pretty pumpy. 

  There are a few pockets have epoxy on/in them that make them a bit slick when you use them as a foot.  

  FA: Craig Keaty (so says my guid book)

Starts with a step across over the water on to a two bolt face up to the ledge where the other two routes start.  Then somewhat thin climbing the rest of the way past 8 bolts to the top.  No real crux unless you think the first move is the crux.
content.protection: 10 bolts to 2 bolt anchor w/ mussy hooks
content.location: Face just left of the upper pond.  Rightmost of the three routes on the face going up the rounded prow.

content.description: Face climbing to a two bolt anchor w/ quicklinks.
content.location: Lower Pond Area   #78 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: Overhang begins about halfway up the climb, but good sized pockets make it a fun pumpy climb.  Crux is around the 3rd clip.
content.location: Number 47 on Marty Karabin's Road Area guide.   It is the climb just to the right of Cowboy.

content.description: Climb pocketed face.
content.location: Upper Pond Area   #46 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: Ledge right to 9 bolt broken face. Route #82 in MK pocket guide
content.location: Lower Pond Wall:   Route uphill from Ninja School and to the right of Rock Lobster.

content.description: Another great climb up broken face!
content.location: Upper Pond Area   #27 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: cool looking bolted line right Great Short Route
Climb big bulge to face.
content.location: Right of the big crack right of Sappy Love Song.

content.description: Thin face moves up bolted face to anchor.  Sustained for bottom half or so.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with mussy hooks
content.location: Located on the nice face just left of In-Seam.

climbs.name: The Casting Couch
climbs.fa: Ronnie Miller, Christopher Bastek, Thomas Park

content.description:
Head up the left arête or go straight up the face using the crack/seam for right hand and left arête for left hand. Straight up the face might be a bit harder than 5.9. 

  Note, this route isn't in the Marty's map of the area. It is two routes right of #23 Christmas Chocolate and on the left arete just left of #24 Casting Shadows. God Save The Ta Tas (another newer route) is the route left of this. 

  It's cleaning up more, but still a good idea to watch out for loose holds here and there.
content.protection: 9 bolts with 2 mussy hooks at the anchors
content.location: Just left of Casting Shadows.

content.description: Follow bolts up crispy face to anchors. Tough on tips but the falls are good.
content.location: Immediately to the left of Bartuni about 6'. (Blisters is misidentified in the Karabin guide from 9-2008. Blisters should be #32 and Time Share should be #31 in that guide.)

content.description: Great climb!
content.location: Upper Pond Area   #28 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide

content.description: A short and stout route. Climb small pockets and slopers past a couple bolts to a cold shut anchor.
content.location: Upper Pond. Located on the face right of the curving crack, Natural Wonder. Rightmost route of 3 bolted lines on the face.

content.description: A great climb; similar to Pocket Puzzle and Pocket Party in style.  Getting off the deck (first 2 bolts) is the crux.  I stayed left at the beginning, which is easier, but may not have been in the spirit of the climb.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Pocket Puzzle.  #37 on Marty Karabin's "Road Area" (9/2008) pocket guide.  Look for the orange bolts.

content.description: Left of Pocket Puzzle

Bouldery start onto a technical face and up various interesting bulge-like features. Pull over last bulge on dark, solid rock. A bit crispy in spots due to newness. Belaying off of the large boulder at the bottom is possible once the leader is well off the ground. It can be started from the direct bottom via the jug or by traversing in from around the corner to the left; same rating either way.
content.protection: 11 bolts and chains at the top. CAUTION: This route is long, 95' or so, use at least a 60 meter rope! STICK CLIPPING the first bolt is recommended due to the fall and tumble potential at that point along the cliff line.
content.location: Line of bolts on the far west (left when looking at the wall) end of the huge Bartuni Wall, left of Mona Lisa. The Big Weld Show is around the corner to the left.

content.description: The Pond is one of the most popular destinations at Queen Creek, and for good reason. There are a multitude of good moderate routes here, mostly on good pocketed rock. The area faces south is generally in the sun and warm, so plan appropriately.
